bioghist.p: The University of Michigan Symphony Band undertook a historic concert tour in 1961, at the height of the cold war, through the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and the Near East. This was a United States State Department cultural exchange tour that lasted 15 weeks and which remains the longest State Department sponsored tour in history.

The Band was directed by renowned conductor William D. Revelli, and traveled accompanied by Frederick Moncrieff, business manager for the tour, George Cavender, assistant band director, Doctor Eugene Winkelman, tour physician, interpreters and additional University and State Department staff. "The Symphony Band musicians were America's cultural emissaries, using music to forge common ground".

The Symphony Band played 88 concerts in ten countries which included six republics of the Soviet Union, Romania, Poland, Lebanon, Greece, Cyprus, Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, and the U.S. It was throughout the tour that band members acquired the materials and memorabilia that make up this collection. Altogether, the 94-member band performed for more than 140,000 concertgoers on the tour.
Band members that participated in this tour have celebrated a number of reunions over the years, the most recent one being in October 2011 for the 50th anniversary celebration of the tour.

scopecontent.p: The collection is composed of eight series arranged by donor. As a result there is highly varying content. Among the materials included are programs, news articles and reviews, pins, band tour photos and memorabilia. A program and photographs printed for the 50th anniversary reunion in 2011 are also part of the collection. The series are arranged in alphabetical order.

The 50th Anniversary Reunion series contains a program and photographic prints of the Symphony Band's reunion in October 2011 compiled by Bruce Galbraith and material from the 2012 return to Russia tour.

The Bruce Galbraith series includes two folders of memorabilia and materials related to the tour. The first contains news clippings, articles, recognitions, letters and telegrams and the second one includes travel guides, plane tickets, concert programs, and a map book.
The Martin Gurvey series includes several Symphony Band concert programs, invitation for band members to a Dinner dance in Jordan, and a hotel key from Poland.

did.unittitle: Invitations, programs and hotel key from Poland

scopecontent.p: The Richard Longfield series contains a Russian newspaper with a review article of one of the band's concerts in Odessa, a leaflet in Georgian and Russian, and a Lebanese newspaper article.
The Diane Mattson Masch series contains several tour posters which are housed separately in the oversized materials.

The Jack McKimmy series is composed of pins from the tour. One of them is from the Goskoncert (piano pin), the soviet organization that sponsored their tour through the Soviet Union. Others include Belarusian and Russian pins.

The Gary Olmstead series contains a CD with digitized photos (416 MB) of the 1961 tour. These include photos taken by him and a compilation of photos from other sources. The photos include general sightseeing shots, concert halls where they played, places visited, views of a concentration camp in Poland (Brzezinka), and some candid shots.

The Stanley Towers series is made up of a scrapbook, compiled by his grandmother Edith Stanley, and two books purchased on the trip; a copy of Uncle Tom's Cabin with Russian preface and guide and a nAnthology of Georgian Poetry.
